Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Laser Ablation System in Support of (U-Th)/He and U/Pb Multidating of Accessory Minerals
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years, geoscientists have increasingly applied the methods of geochronology - the determination of mineral crystallization ages - and thermochronology - the determination of cooling ages - to minerals in sedimentary rocks with the aim of fingerprinting the bedrock sources of these minerals and the cooling histories of those sources. There is great scientific advantage in performing both geochronologic and thermochronologic studies on the same mineral grains, but conventional analytical techniques seldom enable such 'multidating' studies. This grant permits the acquisition of a new ultraviolet laser ablation instrument that, when integrated with existing instruments in the Noble Gas Geochronology and Geochemistry Laboratories at Arizona State University, will establish the first fully automated analytical system for zircon (U-Th)/He thermochronology and U/Pb geochronology.

Broader impacts from this project include opportunities for geology graduate and undergraduate students from outside the ASU community to perform analyses on the system as guest researchers. In addition, the integration of components to build the system will serve as a case study for an on-line 'analytical systems engineering' subject in ASU's B.S. degree program in Exploration Systems Design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the microscope, the sands found in the beds of modern rivers can be seen to contain myriad minerals that preserve a remarkable record of the evolution of the landscapes upstream. To unlock that record, we we search for creative ways to interrogate the chemistry of these minerals. One recently developed method involves the use of ultraviolet lasers to extract isotopes of helium and lead from so-called "accessory" minerals such as zircon, titanite, and rutile.

This grant enabled the purchase of such a laser that, when coupled with  other instrumentation already avaialble at Arizona State University, permits determination of the cooling histories of landscapes based on isotopic analyses of such crystals. These data, in turn, can be used to model erosion rates for a landscape over million-year timescales, or to evaluate the variability of erosion rates in different parts of a landscape provided we have some knowledge of the isotopic charcteristics of the bedrock beneath that landscape. It is the latter utility that promises the greatest societal value. In growing mountainous landscapes with high population densities, for example, we can monitor long-term landsliding histories in order to produce landsliding risk maps. In addtion, such information could be used to assess the frequency of glacial lake outbursts, a process that threatens many high-altitude villages in mountainous regions such as the Himalaya and the Andes.

Incorporation of the acquired instrumentation into our laboratories was done by a team of postdoctoral researchers and graduate students at ASU, many of whom were young women scientists at or near the begining of their professional careers. Facility building exercises such as these provides fundamental "hands-on" STEM educaiton that cannot be replicated in a classroom environment. Now that the instrument is installed, we look forward to many experiential STEM learning opporties for ASU undergraduate students who we welcome into our laboratories. Also of note is that these laboratories are regularly used by students and faculty from other universities who are conducting NSF-funded research, such that our newly acquired laser system can be expected to have a broad impact on geoscience research in the United States.
